VOL. XXXII, No. 55

HOPKINS WINS FINAL
DUAL MEET OF YEAR
Blue Jay Trackmen Go Thru
Season Without Defeat
WASHINGTON EASY PREY
Almost Double Score Made by
Visiting Eastern Shoremen
By winning its fifth and last dual
meet of the year the Johns Hopkins
track team has completed an undefeated season—a feat which has not
been accomplished by a Jay team in
the past ten years.
Washington College was the victim of the Black and Blue cinder
path artists last Saturday morning.
They were forced to take the short
end of a 8272-4272 score. At no
time was the meet in any danger,
and but for the work of Usilton and
Norris the Eastern Shore college
would have been in a sad plight,
indeed. These two men were the
outstanding stars of the day.
Usilton and Norris Star

Usilton won the high hurdles by
inches from Hershey and came
through to win the low hurdles in
the fast time of 25.1 seconds. By a
beautiful sprint he was just able to
beat out Ness for second place in
the 220-yard dash and tied Norris
for first place in the high jump.
In addition to tying Usilton in the
high jump,. Norris won the javelin
throw, was second in the shotput
and broad jump and finished third
in the 100-yard dash. This gave
him a total of seventeen points.
Usilton also amassed seventeen
points, thereby tying Norris for high
point honors for the day.
Hopkins Without Vivell

It must be remembered, however,
that Hopkins was deprived of the
services of its star—Captain Edgar
Vivell—in both hurdle races and the
high jump. He was badly needed
-in the broad jump, when it was
found that two Washington men
were taking first and second place.
Despite his injury, he took one jump
and won the event. Walp, star
javelin thrower, was unable to compete also. Points were lost, undoubtedly, as a result. Fate did not
seem satisfied with these handicaps,
it seems, for in the first event Eddie
Lockard, freshman sprint star,
pulled a muscle in his leg which
forced him out of competition in the
220-yard dash.
The meet, nevertheless, had its
bright spots. Hopkins made a clean
sweep of both the mile run and the
pole vault. Gwinn, Sheibel and
Onerato finished in the order named
in the mile, while the Scheidt brothers and Stafford took care of the
latter-named event.
Berger High Scorer

Jim Berger was again high point
scorer for the Blue Jays, winning
the shotput and the discus throw.
His throw of 116 feet 4Y4 inches
was extremely good when one considers the strong cross wind which
had to be overcome.
The work of Kelly in the twomile was very creditable. He won
the event in fine style and was followed to the tape by Emerson. In
the quarter Hemmetter showed up
well, winning in what is considered
good time for the weather conditions.
(Continued on Page 5, Column 2)

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 15, 1928

SOPHS TO SELECT
COUNCIL DELEGATES
At a recent meeting of the
sophomore class seven men
were nominated for junior
delegates to the Student
Council. The members of the
class who were named are:
McCall,
Norris,
Purcell,
Deets, Houston, Markle and
Linthicum.

Peoria, Ill.
Aug. 26, 1926
Messrs. Larus & Bro. Co.
Richmond, Va.
Dear Sirs:
Justaconfession and an appreciation.
A number of years ago I was a user
of your Edgeworth smoking tobacco.
But like some others,perhaps,I wasled
by alluring advertisements to change.
A few days ago I went into a drug
store to get some tobacco, and on the
case wasthe familiar,can of Edgeworth.
I bought it and Since then have en- ,
joyed old-time comfort.
So my confession is that I made a
mistake in changing to other brands,
and my appreciation is such that Edgeworth will be my Smoke Pal while life
lasts, which may not be long, for I
have passed my 'three score Years and
ten."
Very truly yours,
(signed) E. P. Fishburn

J. C. '29.
Dear Sir,
The article appearing in the last
issue Of the NEWS-LETTER under
the title of "Veritas Vos Liberabit"
and signed H. F. M., Jr., was noteworthy as the opposite of what a
good article should be, the chief
defect being that it dug up a dead
issue and dragged it before the students.
There are, no doubt, those who
will glance at my signature and remark "Ah, a 'Y' man still touchy
about Levering Hall." No, not
that, but I do object to bringing up
issues that have died a natural
death even though they were very
lively in days past. Maybe I am
wrong, however, and the talk of
the drive for a new cage has again
stirred up those on the campus opposed to forward motion in general,
be it drive or progress. However,
I realize this is probably too severe
an indictment of a poor sufferer
from Menckenitis who has overexpanded the thoughts of one-third of
a column into two columns. Lest
I have already rendered myself liable to the same criticism, I had better save my ink.
Sincerely yours,
E. FOSTER DOWELL.

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
We are informed by the Syracuse Daily Sun that the head of the
chemistry department at that institution, a certain Dr. Baker by
name, has very decided ideas of his
own in regard to the ancient collegiate institute known familiarly as
Dr. Baker says,
cramming.
"Cramming is unethical. It is just
as crooked for a student to cram
his head with innumerable details
at the last minute as it is to actually carry written information into
the examination room. What is
hastily collected is usually of an
unimportant nature and will crowd
out the fundamental ideas gathered
during the whole semester." Dr.
Baker's last statement appears to
contradict his first premise, for what
similarity could there be between
cheating and cramming if one
crams unimportant details. We
have encountered very few examinations which were made up of unimportant details. Acting on his
belief, however, the worthy doctor
proceeds to make out examinations
for which cramming would be
worse than useless.

BLOOMER NUMBER OFBLUE JAY CALLS
University Defines
Third Year Students FORTH PRAISE FROM CAMPUS CRITICS BOOKS
The recent confusion among the
undergraduates as to the reuqirements which determine the admission of students to the third year,
is due to the misinterpretation of
the term "second year of residence," Dr. Ames points out. For
the purposes of definition, the university designates and classifies students, not by the actual time spent
at classes, but by the number of
credits. That is: third year students are those having between 60
and 85 credits; fourth year men, 90
or more credits.
Under this classification, those
students considered for admission
to the third year Will be the ones
with 60 credits. This is not a requirement for admission, but a definition of third year men.
As for marks, those sophomores
having an average of 80 or better,
will automatically be accepted in the
third year upon written application.
Those .who have lower averages
must be considered separately. If
a student -is *very poor in most of
his 'subjects, he may still be admitted to the third year upon recommendation of any department in
which he has done especially good
work. "The real reqpirement is that
the student show ari intellectual interest in some one department at
least," Dr. Ames said.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 15, 1928

6

Will Be
SCHOULER LECTURE Elections
Held At Assembly
SERIES CONTINUED
Dr. Fisher Talks on Problem
of Occident and Orient
GOOD

WILL

IS

NEEDED

New Type of Leadership is
Urged By Speaker
"We think of the East as a mysterious and unindustrialized land,"
said Dr. Edgar J. Fisher, dean and
professor of History at Roberts
College in Constantinople, in a lecture on "The Problem of Occident
and Orient", delivered last Thursday afternoon as one of the Schouler lectures.
Dr. Fisher who has been connected with Roberts College for the past
fifteen years, discussed the problems affecting East and West in regard to the establishment of good
will between them. "The West
should realize the disastrousness
of force to its financial interests in
the East," said Dr. Fisher. "In
Asia the Asiatics have prior claims
which they must make good by war
If not by peace. The West must
tecognize these claims as being just,
if amicable relations are to exist
between Orient and Occident.
Western peoples must practice
equality and recognize the cultural
and religious merits of the East.
By so doing we would do away with
those cankers and danger spots that
mar our relations today."
West Needs Leadership

The West needs a new type of
leadership to send to the East. It
should send men of greater sympathy and breadth if the two great
portions of the world are to build
on a basis of confidence. Contacts
in the past have been too much on
the basis of unmitigated force. The
Easterners, therefore, find it difficult to understand us. Turkish Nationalists who succeeded in gaining
freedom from European dominion
at Lausanne are still suspicious.
Though Turkey had great need of
railroads, she refused the help of
foreign capital and said she would
have no more of foreign concessions. "We feel," Dr. Fisher pointed out, "that the East thinks everything we have is beautiful, that the
East needs us." Such an idea is
decidedly erroneous. Turkish Nationalists who instituted a prohibition movement soon after the Great
War were unable to make any
progress until after the evacuation
of the Allied troops because of their
detrimental influence. The West is
not always beautiful or necessary..
Exploitation Must Cease

Exploitation must be ceased. We
must cease to use Eastern lands for
Western benefit and must give up
colonies held by force or markets
which are not on a co-operative
basis. Extra-territorial rights for
foreigners must be surrendered as
they have been in Turkey. When,
under the terms of the Treaty of
Lausanne, European powers gave
up these rights, they became subject to the law of the land and were
no longer exempt from taxation or
custom duties. Consequently, these
foreigners live on the same basis as
the Turk and have no unfair advantage over him which they for- merly possessed. Finally, the West
must adopt a morle tolerant approach to the religion of the East,
remembering that it has its merits
though it be non-Christian. The
East, on the other hand, "must
learn adaptibility rather than mere
slavish copying," said Dr. Fisher. It
must discard what hinders its progress just as Turkey has abolished
the Sultanate, the Califfate, and the
fundamental law of the Koran, es(Continued on Page 4, Column 1)

Elections for President of the
Student Council and delegates to
the A. A. Board will be held directly following the de Tocqueville
contest after the assembly Thursday morning. In addition to the
elections, there is an amendment to

HULLABALOO FEATURED
BY SEVERAL CHANGES
One of the Departures is the
New Small Size

Phone, CAL 1380
AUTO REPAIRING

New departures in several regards will feature the Hullabaloo of
1928-1929. According to John
Eldridge, business manager, the volume will be of considerably smaller
size than in former years. The
most drastic move is embodied in
a resolution before the interfraternity council to the effect that fraternities purchase two pages in the
year-book, instead of four as heretofore. Similarly, all activities that
occupied two pages of space, formerly, will be limited to one.
Contrary to custom, all contracts
for photographing, printing and engraving will be signed this year, instead of at the opening of the university next fall. Eldridge expects,
in this way, to be able to get actual
work on the editorial and advertising ends of the publication under
way simultaneously with the initiating of classes.
Color Plates Next Year

It is expected that the Hullabaloo
will contain colored plates this next
year. Views of the campus, which
heretofore have been either in black
and white or in brown tone, will
be reproduced in actual colors. Section titles, as well, will be illustrated in color.
There are many vacant positions
on the various staffs, and all underclassmen are urged to compete for
them. All undergraduates are eligible to staff membership and opportunity for promotion is very
favorable.

June Week Jay Will
Be Sent To Students
Len Dalsemer, business manager
of the Black and Blue Jay, announced in last week's assembly
that the "June Week Number" issue would appear too late for distribution in the post-office boxes.
Anyone desiring this last issue must
turn in a self-addressed envelope to
Mr: Alyers at the post-office. Envelopes may be obtained upon request from Mr. Myers. Only those
subscribers who attend to this matter will have this final number sent
to them, and each one is asked to
address only one envelope.

campus that it is against the
rules of the Baltimore Fire Department to park cars alongside
the steel ropes across the driveways.

VOL. XXXII, No. 55

HOPKINS WINS FINAL
DUAL MEET OF YEAR
Blue Jay Trackmen Go Thru
Season Without Defeat
WASHINGTON EASY PREY
Almost Double Score Made by
Visiting Eastern Shoremen
By winning its fifth and last dual
meet of the year the Johns Hopkins
track team has completed an undefeated season—a feat which has not
been accomplished by a Jay team in
the past ten years.
Washington College was the victim of the Black and Blue cinder
path artists last Saturday morning.
They were forced to take the short
end of a 8272-4272 score. At no
time was the meet in any danger,
and but for the work of Usilton and
Norris the Eastern Shore college
would have been in a sad plight,
indeed. These two men were the
outstanding stars of the day.
Usilton and Norris Star

Usilton won the high hurdles by
inches from Hershey and came
through to win the low hurdles in
the fast time of 25.1 seconds. By a
beautiful sprint he was just able to
beat out Ness for second place in
the 220-yard dash and tied Norris
for first place in the high jump.
In addition to tying Usilton in the
high jump,. Norris won the javelin
throw, was second in the shotput
and broad jump and finished third
in the 100-yard dash. This gave
him a total of seventeen points.
Usilton also amassed seventeen
points, thereby tying Norris for high
point honors for the day.
Hopkins Without Vivell

It must be remembered, however,
that Hopkins was deprived of the
services of its star—Captain Edgar
Vivell—in both hurdle races and the
high jump. He was badly needed
-in the broad jump, when it was
found that two Washington men
were taking first and second place.
Despite his injury, he took one jump
and won the event. Walp, star
javelin thrower, was unable to compete also. Points were lost, undoubtedly, as a result. Fate did not
seem satisfied with these handicaps,
it seems, for in the first event Eddie
Lockard, freshman sprint star,
pulled a muscle in his leg which
forced him out of competition in the
220-yard dash.
The meet, nevertheless, had its
bright spots. Hopkins made a clean
sweep of both the mile run and the
pole vault. Gwinn, Sheibel and
Onerato finished in the order named
in the mile, while the Scheidt brothers and Stafford took care of the
latter-named event.
Berger High Scorer

Jim Berger was again high point
scorer for the Blue Jays, winning
the shotput and the discus throw.
His throw of 116 feet 4Y4 inches
was extremely good when one considers the strong cross wind which
had to be overcome.
The work of Kelly in the twomile was very creditable. He won
the event in fine style and was followed to the tape by Emerson. In
the quarter Hemmetter showed up
well, winning in what is considered
good time for the weather conditions.
(Continued on Page 5, Column 2)

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER:
J. C. '29.
Dear Sir,
The article appearing in the last
issue Of the NEWS-LETTER under
the title of "Veritas Vos Liberabit"
and signed H. F. M., Jr., was noteworthy as the opposite of what a
good article should be, the chief
defect being that it dug up a dead
issue and dragged it before the students.
There are, no doubt, those who
will glance at my signature and remark "Ah, a 'Y' man still touchy
about Levering Hall." No, not
that, but I do object to bringing up
issues that have died a natural
death even though they were very
lively in days past. Maybe I am
wrong, however, and the talk of
the drive for a new cage has again
stirred up those on the campus opposed to forward motion in general,
be it drive or progress. However,
I realize this is probably too severe
an indictment of a poor sufferer
from Menckenitis who has overexpanded the thoughts of one-third of
a column into two columns. Lest
I have already rendered myself liable to the same criticism, I had better save my ink.
Sincerely yours,
E. FOSTER DOWELL.

was rather inconsiderate, since all
but the orphans must have heard
most of the stories at their mothers'
knees some years back. Of course,
I'm an orphan; I haven't so much
kick coming, but even / managed to
hear nearly all of them in the grades
before high school, when the teacher
used to read to us on Friday afternoons.
What made inc feel bad was the
preface. Miss Mikels tells in words
of one and two syllables how the
adolescent boy or girl can develop
taste by reading the stories she has
chosen and then reading stories in
The Saturday Evening Post or Cosmopolitan Magazine and comparing
the two. "Let the student prepare
a report," she says. "Let the class
read the story, and exonerate either
the author or the student."

for: the English Staff led up to it

Advancement

and reached the top without the help of a college
education. The advantages are with you who graduate from college.

Future

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 15, 1928

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
We are informed by the Syracuse Daily Sun that the head of the
chemistry department at that institution, a certain Dr. Baker by
name, has very decided ideas of his
own in regard to the ancient collegiate institute known familiarly as
Dr. Baker says,
cramming.
"Cramming is unethical. It is just
as crooked for a student to cram
his head with innumerable details
at the last minute as it is to actually carry written information into
the examination room. What is
hastily collected is usually of an
unimportant nature and will crowd
out the fundamental ideas gathered
during the whole semester." Dr.
Baker's last statement appears to
contradict his first premise, for what
similarity could there be between
cheating and cramming if one
crams unimportant details. We
have encountered very few examinations which were made up of unimportant details. Acting on his
belief, however, the worthy doctor
proceeds to make out examinations
for which cramming would be
worse than useless.

BLOOMER NUMBER OFBLUE JAY CALLS
University Defines
Third Year Students FORTH PRAISE FROM CAMPUS CRITICS BOOKS
The recent confusion among the
undergraduates as to the reuqirements which determine the admission of students to the third year,
is due to the misinterpretation of
the term "second year of residence," Dr. Ames points out. For
the purposes of definition, the university designates and classifies students, not by the actual time spent
at classes, but by the number of
credits. That is: third year students are those having between 60
and 85 credits; fourth year men, 90
or more credits.
Under this classification, those
students considered for admission
to the third year Will be the ones
with 60 credits. This is not a requirement for admission, but a definition of third year men.
As for marks, those sophomores
having an average of 80 or better,
will automatically be accepted in the
third year upon written application.
Those .who have lower averages
must be considered separately. If
a student -is *very poor in most of
his 'subjects, he may still be admitted to the third year upon recommendation of any department in
which he has done especially good
work. "The real reqpirement is that
the student show ari intellectual interest in some one department at
least," Dr. Ames said.

The current issue of the Black
and Blue Jay has excited much comment around the campus, for it
marks the second consecutive number of the magazine that has come
out on schedule. And, too, it is the
second consecutive number that has
had a really good, smile-provoking
cover. Ben Kolb's catchy corruption of the popular air from the
Mikado has started a virtual Gilbert
& Sullivan revival on the campus,
and bursts of laughter and nods of
approval everywhere greet this latest effort of our embryo humorists.
It would appear, however, that
the Jay feared approaching too close
to an unheard-of standard of excellence, and inserted a frontispiece
neither funny, appropriate nor interesting. There seemed to have been
an abundance of copy left over from
the Wild West number, and the
managing editor is using it up at any
cost. The dubbing of exam, week
as "Beef Week" is a riduculously
obvious attempt to justify the steer
rampant on the drawing. But this
screaming weakness is decidedly
overshadowed by the quality of a
book, on the whole.
Another very outstanding feature
of the Jay is the symmetrical and
attractive page layout that may be
observed throughout the issue.

of his recent editorials, Don White

SCHOULER LECTURE Elections
Held At Assembly
SERIES CONTINUED
Dr. Fisher Talks on Problem
of Occident and Orient
GOOD

WILL

IS

NEEDED

New Type of Leadership is
Urged By Speaker
"We think of the East as a mysterious and unindustrialized land,"
said Dr. Edgar J. Fisher, dean and
professor of History at Roberts
College in Constantinople, in a lecture on "The Problem of Occident
and Orient", delivered last Thursday afternoon as one of the Schouler lectures.
Dr. Fisher who has been connected with Roberts College for the past
fifteen years, discussed the problems affecting East and West in regard to the establishment of good
will between them. "The West
should realize the disastrousness
of force to its financial interests in
the East," said Dr. Fisher. "In
Asia the Asiatics have prior claims
which they must make good by war
If not by peace. The West must
tecognize these claims as being just,
if amicable relations are to exist
between Orient and Occident.
Western peoples must practice
equality and recognize the cultural
and religious merits of the East.
By so doing we would do away with
those cankers and danger spots that
mar our relations today."
West Needs Leadership

The West needs a new type of
leadership to send to the East. It
should send men of greater sympathy and breadth if the two great
portions of the world are to build
on a basis of confidence. Contacts
in the past have been too much on
the basis of unmitigated force. The
Easterners, therefore, find it difficult to understand us. Turkish Nationalists who succeeded in gaining
freedom from European dominion
at Lausanne are still suspicious.
Though Turkey had great need of
railroads, she refused the help of
foreign capital and said she would
have no more of foreign concessions. "We feel," Dr. Fisher pointed out, "that the East thinks everything we have is beautiful, that the
East needs us." Such an idea is
decidedly erroneous. Turkish Nationalists who instituted a prohibition movement soon after the Great
War were unable to make any
progress until after the evacuation
of the Allied troops because of their
detrimental influence. The West is
not always beautiful or necessary..
Exploitation Must Cease

Exploitation must be ceased. We
must cease to use Eastern lands for
Western benefit and must give up
colonies held by force or markets
which are not on a co-operative
basis. Extra-territorial rights for
foreigners must be surrendered as
they have been in Turkey. When,
under the terms of the Treaty of
Lausanne, European powers gave
up these rights, they became subject to the law of the land and were
no longer exempt from taxation or
custom duties. Consequently, these
foreigners live on the same basis as
the Turk and have no unfair advantage over him which they for- merly possessed. Finally, the West
must adopt a morle tolerant approach to the religion of the East,
remembering that it has its merits
though it be non-Christian. The
East, on the other hand, "must
learn adaptibility rather than mere
slavish copying," said Dr. Fisher. It
must discard what hinders its progress just as Turkey has abolished
the Sultanate, the Califfate, and the
fundamental law of the Koran, es(Continued on Page 4, Column 1)

HULLABALOO FEATURED
BY SEVERAL CHANGES
One of the Departures is the
New Small Size

Phone, CAL 1380
AUTO REPAIRING

New departures in several regards will feature the Hullabaloo of
1928-1929. According to John
Eldridge, business manager, the volume will be of considerably smaller
size than in former years. The
most drastic move is embodied in
a resolution before the interfraternity council to the effect that fraternities purchase two pages in the
year-book, instead of four as heretofore. Similarly, all activities that
occupied two pages of space, formerly, will be limited to one.
Contrary to custom, all contracts
for photographing, printing and engraving will be signed this year, instead of at the opening of the university next fall. Eldridge expects,
in this way, to be able to get actual
work on the editorial and advertising ends of the publication under
way simultaneously with the initiating of classes.
Color Plates Next Year

It is expected that the Hullabaloo
will contain colored plates this next
year. Views of the campus, which
heretofore have been either in black
and white or in brown tone, will
be reproduced in actual colors. Section titles, as well, will be illustrated in color.
There are many vacant positions
on the various staffs, and all underclassmen are urged to compete for
them. All undergraduates are eligible to staff membership and opportunity for promotion is very
favorable.

June Week Jay Will
Be Sent To Students
Len Dalsemer, business manager
of the Black and Blue Jay, announced in last week's assembly
that the "June Week Number" issue would appear too late for distribution in the post-office boxes.
Anyone desiring this last issue must
turn in a self-addressed envelope to
Mr: Alyers at the post-office. Envelopes may be obtained upon request from Mr. Myers. Only those
subscribers who attend to this matter will have this final number sent
to them, and each one is asked to
address only one envelope.
